news.title: Stefon Diggs turns up at Patriots OTAs after viral boat video and Cardi B romance reveal
news.text:
Stefon Diggs was back in action for the Patriots on Monday — one week after the star receiver found himself at the center of controversy over a viral boat video that featured a curious pink powder.

Offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels confirmed Diggs’ attendance Monday at OTAs, telling the media the four-time Pro Bowler is in the know despite past absences from voluntary practices.

“I know he’s staying up to date on the information… I’m not concerned about Stef in that regard,” McDaniels said, according to A to Z Sports.

The Patriots signed Diggs to a three-year, $63.5 million contract in free agency as a new weapon for rising quarterback Drake Maye, who is coming off a promising rookie season.

The former Texans wideout — whose romance with rapper Cardi B became Instagram-official Sunday — stirred buzz over Memorial Day weekend after he was filmed aboard a boat speaking with three women with a pink powder present.

First-year coach Mike Vrabel said Wednesday the team is aware of the footage, adding, “We want to make great decisions on and off the field.”

“… Any conversations that I’ve had with Stefon will remain between him and I and the club,” the former Patriots linebacker stated.

In the wake of the boat video, NFL insiders speculated whether New England would cut ties with Diggs, 31.

“I sort of think all things are on the table and I think really, to me at least, it’s going to boil down to what Stef told [head coach Mike] Vrabel, and how believable it was,” Sports Illustrated’s Albert Breer said Friday during an appearance on 98.5 The Sports Hub.

Scott Zolak, a member of New England’s radio broadcast team, echoed similar remarks.

“It’s not just the boat,” Zolak said. “There are some other things that I’ve heard that put some things in question. Are you all-in here?”

The Vrabel-led Patriots are looking to right the ship after last season’s 4-13 disaster under rookie head coach Jerod Mayo, a fellow New England alum.

He was fired in January.

Diggs spent the last season in Houston, where he tallied 47 receptions for 496 yards and three touchdowns in eight games. He went down with a torn ACL in October.

The Bills traded Diggs to the Texans last offseason after four seasons in Buffalo.

Diggs and Cardi B, 32, fueled romance rumors back in February.
news.summary: A week ago, the star receiver found himself at the center of controversy over a viral boat video that featured a curious pink powder.
news.author: Jaclyn Hendricks

news.title: Stefon Diggs returns to Patriots practice after video on boat goes viral
news.text:
FOXBORO — Wide receiver Stefon Diggs, one of the Patriots’ highest-profile offseason additions, returned to organized team activities practices Monday at Gillette Stadium.

The four-time Pro Bowl selection wasn’t present for practice last week after a video surfaced on the internet with him on a boat during Memorial Day Weekend, passing out an unknown pink substance to a group of women.

Diggs ran onto the practice fields Monday, telling the media, “Nice to see you,” before participating in a limited capacity as he continues to recover from a torn ACL suffered midway through the 2024 season.

“He’s here today, and we’re excited to have an opportunity to work with the guys that are out here and available to us,” offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels said Monday before practice when asked about Diggs missing practice the week before. “So I know he’s staying up on the information, the material. And there’s so many things and opportunities for us to teach all our guys going forward, between the rest of the practices here in the spring and then going into the summer and the many days we have before we actually kick the ball off in September. So, I’m not concerned about Steph in that regard.”

Diggs went through individual drills with wide receivers but did not participate in 11-on-11s, staying off to the side to continue rehabbing his knee.
news.summary: Patriots offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels gave an update on Stefon Diggs as the wide receiver returned to practice.

news.title: Amid boat video controversy, Stefon Diggs returns to Patriots OTA practices
news.text:
It’s been an eventful couple of days for new Patriots receiver Stefon Diggs.

Less than week after the veteran receiver sparked plenty of discourse after he was taped in a viral video with an unidentified substance, Diggs was present and accounted for during the Patriots’ organized team activity (OTA) session Monday at Gillette Stadium. 

Diggs was not present at OTAs last week following the release of the video of himself partying on a boat in Florida — but did participate in practices with the Patriots two weeks ago. OTAs are voluntary practices at this stage of the NFL preseason. 

“It’s a voluntary part of the year, we know that. I don’t know if we’ve ever had perfect attendance at these things in general,” Patriots offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels said. “As a coach, selfishly, you love it when they’re all here because you feel you’ve got them all in the classroom, the field and all the rest of it. He’s here today, and we’re excited to have an opportunity today to work with the guys who are out here and available to us.

“I know he’s staying up on the information and material. There are so many opportunities for us to teach all our guys going forward between the rest of the practices here in the spring, and then going into the summer and the many days we have before we actually kick the ball off in September. I’m not concerned about Stefon in that regard.”

Despite Diggs’ potential as a dynamic No. 1 receiving target for Drake Maye in 2025, the former All-Pro might already be on shaky ground with Mike Vrabel and New England’s coaching staff weeks ahead of training camp. 

The viral video featured Diggs on a boat with several women in swimsuits — with the wide receiver at one point possessing a pouch that contained an unidentified pink substance.

Last week, Vrabel did not go into detail over the video and if there were any disciplinary measures doled out against Diggs. 

“Well, it’s something that we’re aware of. Obviously, we want to make great decisions on and off the field,” Vrabel said. “We’re hoping that with our time here on the field today, that when we don’t have a script and we’re on the call periods, that we’re making great decisions.”

On Friday, 98.5 The Sports Hub’s Scott Zolak shared that the Patriots were at least considering releasing Diggs following this misstep.

“It’s not just the boat,” Zolak said. “There are some other things that I’ve heard that put some things in question. Are you all-in here?”

Amid this controversy, Diggs was back with his teammates on Monday — although he remains limited as he works his way back from an ACL tear he suffered in October 2024. 

Even though Diggs was not taking part in 11-on-11 drills, he did reel in a few catches from Maye during Monday’s session. 

“He’s working hard,” Patriots wide receivers coach Todd Downing said of Diggs ahead of Monday’s practice. “I think there’s a little carryover with the stuff he did in Buffalo with (Brian) Daboll back in the day. So there’s a little bit of a refresher course. But yeah, he’s been working hard.”
news.summary:
"He's here today, and we're excited to have an opportunity today to work with the guys who are out here and available to us."

NYT Connections is one of several increasingly popular word games made by the New York Times. news.title: Boulder attack updates: Suspect booked on charges after 'act of terror'
news.text:
A suspect was booked on a range of charges after allegedly carrying out an "act of terrorism" on a pedestrian mall in Boulder, Colorado, on Sunday afternoon, using what police are describing as a "makeshift flamethrower" against a crowd of pro-Israel demonstrators.

Eight people were hospitalized with burns, Boulder Police said in an update Sunday night. The victims' ages ranged from 52 to 88, and they were all taken to local hospitals, police said.

One victim was in critical condition, police said.

The suspect, identified by the FBI as 45-year-old Mohamed Sabry Soliman, was allegedly heard yelling "Free Palestine" while using a "makeshift flamethrower" and throwing an incendiary device at the crowd, according to Special Agent in Charge Mark Michalek.

Soliman was taken into custody without incident and transferred to a hospital where he was examined, police said.

Soliman is being held on $10,000,000 bond, according to the Boulder County Jail, which listed a range of felony charges against him, including use of an incendiary device.

FBI Director Kash Patel said officials were investigating the incident as a "targeted terror attack." The FBI believes the attack was "ideologically motivated violence," according to "early information, the evidence and witness accounts," Deputy Director Dan Bongino added.

The attack in Boulder comes at a time of heightened violence, including high-profile incidents against the Jewish community.

The pro-Israel demonstration was a Run for Their Lives walk, aiming to raise awareness about the remaining hostages in Gaza. The organization hosts global run and walk events, "calling for the immediate release of the hostages held by Hamas," according to its website.

Leo Terrell, head of the antisemitism task force at the Justice Department, said that an "incendiary device" was thrown at participants in the walk.

"This was not an isolated incident," Terrell continued. "This antisemitic terrorist attack is part of a horrific and escalating wave of violence targeting Jews and their supporters simply for being Jewish or standing up for Jewish lives," he said.

The attack happened on the eve of a Jewish holiday, Shavuot, "making it all the more chilling and cruel," Terrell said.

A spokesperson for the organization, Miri Kornfeld, said in a statement to ABC News said a man who was leading the walk described the scene as "the floor burning beneath them."

All upcoming Run for Their Lives events have been canceled until further notice, Kornfeld said, who was not at the walk in Boulder.

President Donald Trump has been briefed on the "targeted terror attack," a senior White House official told ABC News.

"Hate-filled acts of any kind are unacceptable. While details emerge, the state works with local and federal law enforcement to support this investigation," Colorado Gov. Jared Polis wrote on X, describing the incident as a "heinous act of terror."

Boulder Police, while calling the attack a "tragedy" and "unacceptable," initially stopped short of calling the incident terrorism and did not want to speculate on the suspect's move, according to Chief Stephen Redfearn.

The incident occurred just before 1:30 p.m. on Sunday at the intersection of 13th Street and Pearl Street.

Police responded to reports of a man with a weapon and that people were being set on fire.

When they arrived, there were multiple victims at the scene with injuries consistent with burns, police said. Police said four of the victims were taken to Boulder Community Hospital and two others were airlifted to a burn unit in Aurora. Apart from the victim with serious injuries, the others were believed to be more minor, Redfearn said.

Last month, two Israeli Embassy staffers were shot and killed in Washington, D.C. in what was labeled as an "act of terror."

The shooting sparked outrage and has been condemned as an "unspeakable" act of antisemitism after officials said the suspect, who is in custody, shouted "free, free Palestine" following the shooting.

In April, the residence of Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, who is Jewish, was targeted by an arsonist who allegedly made two Molotov cocktails from Heineken bottles he had at home and threw them inside the governor’s mansion after breaking a window with a hammer, according to court documents.

The attack happened after the governor had posted about celebrating Passover with his family.

This is a developing story. Please check back for updates.
news.summary: Police in Colorado are responding to a "heinous" attack at a pedestrian mall in the city that they say left several victims.
news.author: Jeffrey Cook,Leah Sarnoff,Luke Barr,Vanessa Navarrete

"This was not an isolated incident," Terrell continued. "This antisemitic terrorist attack is part of a horrific and escalating wave of violence targeting Jews and their supporters simply for being Jewish or standing up for Jewish lives," he said.

The attack happened on the eve of a Jewish holiday, Shavuot, "making it all the more chilling and cruel," Terrell said.

A spokesperson for the organization, Miri Kornfeld, said in a statement to ABC News said a man who was leading the walk described the scene as "the floor burning beneath them."

All upcoming Run for Their Lives events have been canceled until further notice, Kornfeld said, who was not at the walk in Boulder.

President Donald Trump has been briefed on the "targeted terror attack," a senior White House official told ABC News.

"Hate-filled acts of any kind are unacceptable. While details emerge, the state works with local and federal law enforcement to support this investigation," Colorado Gov. Jared Polis wrote on X, describing the incident as a "heinous act of terror."

Boulder Police, while calling the attack a "tragedy" and "unacceptable," initially stopped short of calling the incident terrorism and did not want to speculate on the suspect's move, according to Chief Stephen Redfearn.

The incident occurred just before 1:30 p.m. on Sunday at the intersection of 13th Street and Pearl Street.

Police responded to reports of a man with a weapon and that people were being set on fire.

When they arrived, there were multiple victims at the scene with injuries consistent with burns, police said. Police said four of the victims were taken to Boulder Community Hospital and two others were airlifted to a burn unit in Aurora. Apart from the victim with serious injuries, the others were believed to be more minor, Redfearn said.

Last month, two Israeli Embassy staffers were shot and killed in Washington, D.C. in what was labeled as an "act of terror."

The shooting sparked outrage and has been condemned as an "unspeakable" act of antisemitism after officials said the suspect, who is in custody, shouted "free, free Palestine" following the shooting.

In April, the residence of Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, who is Jewish, was targeted by an arsonist who allegedly made two Molotov cocktails from Heineken bottles he had at home and threw them inside the governor's mansion after breaking a window with a hammer, according to court documents.

The attack happened after the governor had posted about celebrating Passover with his family.
news.summary: A suspect was booked on a range of charges after allegedly carrying out an "act of terrorism" on a pedestrian mall in Boulder, Colorado.

news.title: 007 First Light is the name of the new James Bond game, reveal coming this week
news.text:
When you talk about matches made in gaming heaven, IO Interactive and a James Bond game is certainly one of them – on paper, at least. The Hitman developer's penchant for creating stealthy, surprising, and emergent gameplay moments makes it the logical choice to create a new 007 game, something that's been a long time coming. Well, this week you'll finally get to see the studio's highly anticipated Project 007, which now has an official title: 007 First Light.

For the most part, James Bond games of yesteryear aligned themselves with whatever major film release was dropping at the time, or attempted to recreate iconic moments from the movies. Some are still hailed today as essential, must-play games – others are remembered for being totally awful. What's shocking, though, is that it has been well over a decade since a new experience as the world's most famous spy arrived – 2012's mediocre 007 Legends was his last videogame outing. IO Interactive will soon be changing that, however, with 007 First Light. Previously referred to simply as Project 007, all that was known about it was that it would be a "wholly original Bond story" where players "would earn their 00 status in the very first James Bond origin story."

That's a tempting proposition, and IOI's glowing reputation thanks to the superb Hitman series nudges 007 First Light even higher up my personal list of most-anticipated new PC games. After months of sneaking in the shadows, it'll soon be time to see what IOI has cooked up.

A post on the newly created 007 First Light X account, shared by IOI, says that a "mission brief is headed your way soon," and the accompanying graphic confirms that the full game reveal will arrive "this week." With the Summer Game Fest showcase airing on Friday, June 6, there's a very high likelihood that this is when we'll get to see 007 First Light.

I'll caveat this excitement by saying that nowhere does it mention there will be any proper gameplay snippets – this could well be a stylized reveal trailer or a montage of cinematics and cutscenes. Regardless, it's great to see this game, which has been pretty much silent since it was first announced all the way back in 2020, is finally ready to get shown off. Hopefully this also means the 007 First Light release date isn't too far away either.

For more, check out our list of the biggest upcoming PC games that may well get some air time this week as well. For something you can sink your teeth into right away, here are some of the best stealth games.

You can follow us on Google News for daily PC games news, reviews, and guides. We've also got a vibrant community Discord server, where you can chat about this story with members of the team and fellow readers.

news.title: 007: First Light Is Hitman Dev's James Bond Game, Will Be Revealed This Week
news.text: With Summer Game Fest coming at the end of the week, the deluge of video game news that accompanies the annual event is set to begin soon. IO Interactive has kicked things off with the news that Project 007--the studio's new adventure starring famous spy James Bond--will officially be known as 007: First Light, and the game is set to be revealed later this week. 007: First Light is a "wholly original Bond origin story" according to the game's official website, that will let players "step into the shoes of the world's favorite Secret Agent to earn their 00 status." No other new information about First Light was shared, including which platforms it will appear on--the only known platform so far is Nintendo Switch 2, after a brief teaser appeared during the Switch 2 Direct in April. 007: First Light teaser imagePreviously, IO Interactive CEO Hakan Abrak mentioned that First Light will be "the start of a new trilogy" focused on James Bond, and that IO's version of Bond will not be based on any other version of the character. "What's exciting about that project is that we actually got to do an original story," Abrak said, "so it's not a gamification of a movie. It's completely beginning and becoming a story, hopefully for a big trilogy out there in the future." 007: First Light was one of many third-party games confirmed for Nintendo Switch 2 during the Switch 2 Direct, along with From Software's next project The Duskbloods, Final Fantasy VII Remake Intergrade, Yakuza 0: Director's Cut, and Street Fighter 6. First-party Nintendo titles announced during the event include Donkey Kong Bananza, Mario Kart World, and Kirby Air Riders. Summer Game Fest Live kicks off at 2 PM PT / 5 PM ET on Friday, June 6. While 007: First Light has not been confirmed for the show, a mysterious game called Ill has been teased for the show, as well as an appearance by Kojima Productions head Hideo Kojima.

news.title: James Bond Game From Hitman Dev Has a New Title, 007 First Light, Official Reveal This Week
news.text:
Finally, more five years after its first announcement, we're about to get our first real look at IO Interactive's new James Bond game. Initially teased as Project 007, the official title is 007 First Light, and it's set for a reveal sometime this week.

In a post to Twitter/X today, developer IO Interactive showed a still image of presumably James Bond in silouette lit faintly by a single beam of light, with text reading "First Light 007" and "Game reveal this week." It included a hashtag "#EarnTheNumber", likely a reference to a fact that the project is an origin story centered around Bond "earning" his 007 number.

The post didn't include any further details, but it seems likely we'll see this game at one of the showcases planned for the coming week as a part of Summer Game Fest, Summer of Gaming, or one of the other gaming events typical for the first week of June.

007 First Light was first revealed back in 2020 as Project 007, and since then we've learned very, very little about it. We know it's a James Bond origin story and is a wholly original piece of work rather than retreading the events of any particular film. More recently, IO Interactive CEO Hakan Abrak said he hopes this will be the start of a new trilogy of games, though unfortunately the studio's beloved Hitman franchise is on hiatus while IOI works on this game. We also learned just this past April that in addition to PC, PlayStation, and Xbox, it's getting a Nintendo Switch 2 release.

Rebekah Valentine is a senior reporter for IGN. You can find her posting on BlueSky @duckvalentine.bsky.social. Got a story tip? Send it to rvalentine@ign.com.
news.summary: Finally, more five years after its first announcement, we're about to get our first real look at IO Interactive's new James Bond game. Initially teased as Project 007, the official title is 007 First Light, and it's set for a reveal sometime this week.
